commentBody:
As Barry is wont to say:

SRSLY????
Too easy and weak theme.
This puzzle has given me a lot to think about. Very introspective.

Yikes, lost my 10 day streak. BELESPRIT is a new one by me, spent as much time on that as I did the rest of the puzzle combined. In the end, I was confident of all the crossings, but no Gold Star. The mistake? ITtY/tEAR. Tear is an appropriate synonym for scorch, and itty bitty is also a valid response to the down clue. Lovely
I was probably one thing away from this puzzle being impossible, with all the names/french things. Like, ACCRA, COHEN, HMART, and EIRE was a brutal corner for a Wednesday.
10/10. Theme was not too easy to give everything away, but also not too hard to be of no use. Used it to help with the kardashians, but not the brontes. Just right for a Wednesday
Type O is not a universal donor. Only O negative is. Saying “type O” is the universal donor is factually incorrect, O positive cannot be given to all blood types.
I was embarrassed to even begin to know how to spell the K sisters but to my credit I got some letters wrong.

This puzzle went from the sublime (the Brontës) to the ridiculous (the Kardashians). Cute theme nonetheless. I liked little buggy for ANT.

I was happy to see Anthony DOERR in the middle of the puzzle. His novels, All The Light We Cannot See and Cloud Cuckoo Land are delightful reads.
I loved the trios of women: a fun juxtaposition of old, new, and timeless. The clue for 21D made a tired phrase fresh again with a lovely melody!

Crossing Haka with Kourtney?  Not being much into the Kardashians or anything of that ilk, but having at least heard the name on TV, I had her name starting with a “C”.  OK, now I see all their names start with “K”, but requiring that knowledge of an unusual spelling to solve this puzzle seems like a stretch, given the cross.  Maybe I’m too old or just unhip.
Fantastic! Good theme concept, chefs kiss theme answers. ANT was the cherry on top.

I certainly knew THETHREESISTERS - so delicious! -  but got tripped up by not realizing that the lower three sisters’ names all began with a K rather than a C which, I’m sure, shows how nerdily out of step I am with popular culture. I just asked my husband if he could name three Kardashian sisters and he floated “Kim?” I replied, “Good! And… ?”. He said, “Bethany?”. Ha ha! I said, “They all start with a K.” and he replied “Karen?” So at least I’m not absolutely the most out of date person on the planet!
It was a fun theme. Right level  difficulty for a Wed.  I don't know the Kardashians but I know their names start with Ks, so I was able to figure it out.
I guess I have to admire the audacious concept of teaming one sublimely talented trio with a ridiculously overexposed troika of  triviality. Ah well, parts of this puzzle were pretty good.

I can see it now...a blockbuster movie that combines "Wuthering Heights" with "Keeping Up With The Kardashians."  The plot line of the novel will have to be adjusted to fit the SoCal location and particular family dynamics, but there's enough overlap that the toggling should be easy...Kim Kardashian is Katherine (name changed slightly because of the Kardashians' obsession with the letter "K" --- their memoir is likely to be called "Crying in K-Mart"), Edgar Linton is played by Kanye West, Nelly is Khloe, but who will play Heathcliff, that's the real puzzle! Maybe Michael Cera? Luckily, Jill Singer is also a filmmaker (see her excellent constructor's notes) so I'm sure she's already been working on this: you can tell from this puzzle she's a belle esprit. Soon to be on Netflix. I'm in!

How ironic to have the Brontë sisters sharing a theme with the Kardashians. I can't think of two families who have less in common. 

Seemingly appropriate symmetry of BELESPRIT and COMIC BOOK. 

An amusing puzzle.  Thanks, Jill.

For those who want to know more about the PETS mentioned in the clue for 28D, there is a recent article in the NYT Science section about them: - https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/13/science/ball-pythons-social-snakes.html Turns out they are quite cuddly creatures - with each other, that is, and not (presumably) with their human owners.
Love that Crying in HMart made an appearance. What a wonderful book, highly recommend for a good cry and to help find meaning in losing someone close to you from cancer.

Here I live THE THREE SISTERS are a . geological formation, and major tourist attraction, just west of Sydney. They are part of our Blue Mountains, not to be confused with the Jamaican ones. Well worth the visit.

I was having such a lovely time with the puzzle until I got KIM on the crosses as the first of the modern sisters and the lovely feeling went away. But any puzzle with Leonard Cohen can't be all bad. https://youtu.be/EImVucJO7Ok?si=hg_8He7X8Z1QoSxh

Mon Dieu!  It was fun to have a lot of French cooked into this delicious gateau, but the K sisters teamed with the B sisters was tough to swallow.  I was through the puzzle until I came upon KIM and had passed right by the others.  I had POU____Y and thought, could that be the POURTNOY family? Wrong on two counts. It wasn't Portnoy, but I have no complaints, because I had a good laugh about it.

I enjoyed this one so much. Thank you, Jill Singer, you gave us a lovely Wednesday puzzle, and on top of it I learned how to spell the K sisters' names, a skill I HOPE never to need.

Note to Sam: Olga, Irina and Masha, those Chekhov sisters, seemed listless and bored, but there was a lot more than ennui happening in that play.

I expect to see complaints about the Kardashians invading the NYT crossword like so many horned vipers, but pop culture does have its place here. Smart of the constructor to include some 19h century pop culture to balance it. I was also impressed by the placement of some reading-related clues at the top of the grid, contrasting with entries like ENEWS, IMING and EGO at the bottom. Both sets of sisters were right at home!

I had a grand time solving this puzzle. The fill was rich and appetizing, and I was very much on the wavelength (even when singing "Somewhere Over the Rainbow" to get to the last words.) Thank you to the constructor! I even found it interesting, in a peculiar kind of way, to have two very different trios of sisters in the same puzzle. We go from classical literature and writing talent to straight-up T.V. and a a reality show. And with the marketing chops of Kris Kardashian, the mommager, the family has truly milked T.V. for what it's worth. I've never watched the show, nor do I watch E NEWS, but there's no escaping knowing their names, and that's all due to her work. Whereas some might balk at having both trios side by side due to the disparate nature of their claim to fame, I found it quite interesting precisely because of the contrast and the cheeky way it illustrates the changes brought about by technology. A less philosophical and simpler kind of pleasure came from the inclusion of Leonard COHEN, and I leave you here with him and "Dance Me to The End of Time," hopefully inspiring everyone to dance a little and, on this Thanksgiving week and always, be grateful for those we love and get to dance with through life, even if metaphorically. https://youtu.be/NGorjBVag0I?feature=shared

Loved completing this puzzle!  

My single complaint on the 1 Across clue  — should have read “Long (for)”

Fresh and fun.

BEL ESPRIT is new to me. Love learning new phrases!

Loved this puzzle! As they said of Clara Bow — it really HAS IT. A little something for everyone, plus some nice controversial entries for those who need to squabble a little or complain about something every time. I, however, HOPE to remain as ZEN as a sleepy TORTOISE— why oh why CAN’T I??

All this time wasted on reading Chekhov when I should’ve just been keeping up with the Kardashians.

Where has everything gone? Where is it all? Oh my God, my God! I've forgotten everything.

I did not enjoy the puzzle, not really, because I struggled with it, and not in a fun way. It wasn't wordplay that defeated me, or wit, but simply names and words I did not know.

Today's experience was also hard for me emotionally, as it always hurts to realize I know the names of at least some of the K family, despite my best efforts to learn nothing about them, and to forget what I have unwittingly learned.

There was so much trivia I had to look up! All those proper names crossing with the Chinese symbol were my personal natick today. I also had no idea what that Flyer thing was, I have not heard of BEL ESPRIT, and there were some names around there that were either unknown to me or just forgotten. Also, HMART... I suppose it's some store? Looks like random letters if you don't know it, which I don't, duh. Basically, the puzzle made me realize I know the Ks better than some other stuff... Ouch.

I still don't get how Party pooper solves to PILL. Could somebody please explain?

I don’t know why the use of two answers with ‘the’ and two with ‘oh’ irks me. It shouldn’t. It really doesn’t matter. Or does it? I can never tell. It probably says more about me than anything else. I think I’ll have a lie down. 

As you were.
A bit too much trivia today for my liking.

Emily Brontë took literature to new "Heights."

(And her pen name rings a Bell.)
I think 41 down must surely be wrong. The Rhône has greater flow into the Mediterranean than The Nile? I want to see some sourcing on that!

I am trying to get better at seeing the good in all things. 

Today, for example, I found myself grateful that so much entertainment-based trivia was packed into one puzzle, which hopefully will prevent said trivia from polluting many other puzzles (by the law of the conservation of uselessness--whiich I suspect does not, but I hope for humanity's sake does, exist.)





blah blah emus

Challenging Wednesday,

upped my average time a bit,

gold star, nice surprise!
Almost beat my Wednesday best! I suppose there are some perks to being chronically online (the Kardashians otherwise offer us little as a society)
Interesting puzzle. Although I would have preferred the trio of Faith, Hope and Charity, as opposed to Plague, Pestilence and Disease. Seen here with Kapital K’s.

Well, that  was an unusual Wednesday.  Neither set of sisters' names came easily (although I got THE THREE SISTERS with no crosses), and I was almost tripped up on the K spelling of the second set.  I had cHLOE until my final review showed ScIT, so I changed that and looked back over everything and noticed cOURTNEY and KIM, and realized it was *that* invasive species that had somehow made it into my brain and fixed the final K.

In the end, I found it very enjoyable because it took longer than a typical Wednesday, and that's always a good thing.
Can’t help feel that “good looking couple”, while solvable, doesn’t quite parse. “Couple of lookers” would have been better.

I solved 66A, "Clever person," through the crossings, and when I saw the answer I thought, "What the heck is a BELESPRIT?"  It wasn't until I read the Wordplay column that I saw the answer is meant to be read "BEL ESPRIT," which is actually a term I know, but just could not see in the answer.  D'oh!

When I got the 1st of the top three, I immediately got the other two. When I got the 1st of the bottom three, I needed crosses to help out with the others.

I have hope that I'm successfully avoiding a bit of the worst of pop culture.

Fun fact: neither root words nor their stems are actually covered in Botany 101.

(Re-reads and leaves.)

There were a couple of locations that just seemed so obscure that I was rechecking for the gold star even after I finished. Never heard of HMART or the memoir or of BELESPRIT, so is it possible that the editors got something wrong? Could there be a word for long with a K in the third position?

All fair, but challenging.

The Kardashians don't have anything to do with Roger Clemens, do they?

Lighthearted fun, much needed today.   For a good laugh scroll down to JLin's thread from last night including this from NancyJ: 

"A priest, a pastor, and a rabbit walked into a clinic to donate blood. The nurse says to the rabbit: "What's your blood type?"

The rabbit replied with great sadness, "I'm probably a type O". "
Doesnt the Nile have a higher flow rate than the Rhone?

Too many proper nouns for my liking. I never look them up - or anything else for that matter. One might as well just look at the answers. Where’s the fun in that? I’d rather loose my streak. I feel like I accomplished something by solving today’s puzzle.
Every school child in New York State should know the three sisters, crucial in Haudenosonee farming. But bel esprit was a new one for me.

This is, at the very least, the worst Wednesday puzzle of the year. It literally appears to be AI generated based on the random (and probably recycled) forced trivia combined with its incredibly lazy and thoughtless theme. 
Google flexed PPP, titles, and foreign terms everywhere. 
Not a Wednesday difficulty overall. 
Very unbalanced.

Did I love this puzzle because so much of it was in my wheelhouse? I'm proud to know the literary trio, despite never having finished any of their novels; embarrassed to know the television trio, and how to spell their names; and was familiar with the agricultural trio. Although "Meso-American" in the clue seemed a bit limiting, as the Three Sisters were cultivated by the (North American) Eastern Woodland nations--as far north as Michigan and Ontario; and Ms. Singer describes seeing their use in Peru. For anyone who may wish to know more, may I recommend Charles Mann's excellent cultural history *1491*. Also nice to see [Schumann] clued to CLARA, and COHEN clued as a poet: I remember having a volume of Cohen's poetry (not intended as song lyrics), and I had a high school English teacher who assigned us Cohen lyrics to analyze as poetry. He had a (post-graduation) affair with one of his students. (The teacher, not Cohen.) And, of course, those of you who know my (pop-) musical tastes will_expect_me to post a clip of_MY_favorite sister act: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bxCs25Cnhwg (Curiously, like the Brontës, they have a brother who never became quite as well known.)

Loved this puzzle but a little unsettled by the pairing of the Brontes with the Kardashians...

Also enjoyed the rabbit joke quoted a few comments below!

Tough one for me, and had to look up some things but managed to get through it. Thought it was a quite clever theme when I finally caught on. Rather amazing puzzle find today. A Thursday from April 3, 2014 by David Benkof and Jeff Chen. Theme answers in that one: CHANUKAHMENORAH CHAOSTHEORY CHARLOTTEBRONTE CHAINSMOKED And then the 'reveal': CHCHCHCHCHANGES Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/3/2014&g=36&d=A I'm done. ..

The side trips made this solve especially rich: • COHEN – Hearing him sing in my head, that rich, heart-moving voice of his. • Learning HAKA, especially viewing this one-minute video linked by Rex’s sub today: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N__OF41CqoY . Powerful. • Thinking that ICU must have been clued with the “sentence” angle many times before in all the crossword venues, then finding out that no it hasn’t, not even once. In fact, after seeing how dull all the ICU clues have been, giving CLAPS for originality and spark. • GATEAU got me thinking about its lovely rhymes (CHATEAU, PLATEAU, BATEAU), which to me thinking about EAU-ending words I love: nouveau, bureau, chapeau, Juneau, portmanteau, trousseau, flambeau … and the images of Peter Sellers as Inspector Clouseau. Other likes include the lovely word ERSATZ, the schwa-de-vivre of eight answers ending in that sound, the cutest-ever clue for ANT – [A little buggy?] – and learning BEL ESPRIT. Yes, a rich and very pleasing start to the day. Thank you so much for this, Jill!

Had the literary references but failed on the big butted Kardashians. I feel good about myself for that.

Thank you Jill, Ya'at'eeh

Really happy to learn of the culinary sisters!

Now, to work that into a conversation…
with someone who will *get* it…

toss in a BEL ESPRIT for flavor…

maybe even casually reference the Brontë fam,

and boom! 

CC drops mic. 🎤 

Why have a conversation with a friend
if I can’t *win* said convo? 
Amiright?
I do not like being reminded of one of those sister sets. But it was a good puzzle anyway.

What a fun idea for a theme, and for me anyway,  just the right level of difficulty for a Wednesday. 

Well done, Jill.
Don't appreciate that odious "K" family invading my Crossword...just sayin'......

ITSY instead of ITtY

Took me a while to catch that mistake. 

I was not happy when tEAR solved for [Scorch] but after I placed it I didn’t notice it again. 

Stupid mistake. Fun puzzle. Thanks, Jill Singer!

i enjoyed learning "bel esprit" (fortunately all the crosses were kind). So I offer this example  of its usage (judging from today's comments):
As a bel esprit, I feel obliged to make clear how much I despise the Kardashians.
TIL the term BEL ESPRIT (and thanks Sam for parsing it!) A nice find and a cute puzzle!
It was a fun puzzle but two OHs and two THEs seems like lazy construction.
I read Jane Eyre for the first time earlier this year. Man, was that a good one. Charlotte, that one was.
Loved it. Set a new PR!

BTW, some nifty grid building here, slotting in theme names with 3-, 4-, 5-, 5-, 8- and 9-letter counts, plus a spanning revealer, and not only having the box filled cleanly but with variety and interest in the non-theme answers as well.  Brava, Jill!
Fun solve — only a little mortified that the Kardashians made it into a CW theme together w the Brontes but well here we are.

Wednesday's puzzle has a charming edge,
Like a Flexible Flyer racing down "la neige"!

Throughout, underlying its mystery,
The work of a soul with a "bel esprit"!

Joyeaux Noel!

You know, there are THREE SISTERS in _King Lear_ that would fit Just Fine ...instead of the set of K-people who (in my opinion) add nothing to our cultural milieu...

Did the Editors of hte NYT Crossword Puzzle Kingdom mistakenly believe that we wanted to learn French?  Is this the new wrinkle in PuzzleLand?--vocabulary words and phrases for all!  
We can have our GATEAU and eat it, too?

FWIW, I had a really hard time leaving ACHE/HMART in the puzzle.  
BTW, I'm not willing to turn my nose up at K-MART; during the several years when PhysicsDaughter was on a particularly expensive drug (available as a generic in Canada, but not in the US) K-MART charged only $499 per month--signifcantly less than Walgreen's, CVS, and Rite-Aid.  

This was actually a fine puzzle; it's not Jill's fault that she churns up memories...  No doubt she is a BEL ESPRIT... (and I find the assigned meaning of "clever person" to be quite a stretch.  "Lovely spirit" should be compliment enough.)

There are also three sisters in Glencoe, near Ballachulish in Scotland.
HMart was in a crossword not long ago - there is even one in London.
Just when I learned that the phrase is itty-bitty, along comes itsy.
I was only ignorant on a couple of names and the rest was quite easy. No sport!
Any puzzle that gives a shoutout to SELENA is good in my book!
Very clever fitting that all in. Well done!

People frequently grouse about odd or uncommon words and names in these puzzles. And sometimes they can seem pretty contrived. But I've tried (and failed) to put together even a simple crossword puzzle, and there are times when, instead of blowing up a whole section of it, you're stuck with some klutzy fill. Try it sometime and you'll appreciate what a constructor goes through.

Despite having a few unknown (to me) names, this was a smooth solve that needed no lookups. That's a good thing, it's only Wednesday!

I did have one TYPEO but it was easy to find.

Learned a few new things.... I was unfamiliar (but now fascinated) with the plant trio. In my part of the world THE THREE SISTERS is a photogenic mnt in the Canadian Rockies.

Bronte sisters= Literati

Kardashians= Litterati.

A nice puzzle and an interesting revealer. I would have preferred the Polgar sisters to the Kardashians though. Judit is commentating the world chess championships at the moment, doing a stellar job as usual. What a legend!

About THE THREE SISTERS:
I learned about these interplanted crops as a youngster, reading Lois Lenski's book _Indian Captive_, about Mary Jemison.  She was taken during the French and Indian War by a Seneca war party (who killed the rest of the family) and lived the rest of her life with the tribe, refusing 'repatriation.'  Some details of her life were slightly altered by the author, as Lenski's books were written for children.  (She was a prolific writer and illustrator, and I read all of her 'middle-elementary' books that our library had.)

I got eventually solved the puzzle, despite not knowing Pulitzer winners, H Mart, American politicians, etc.

But can anybody explain to me what the connection between REG and pumps? It's not making any sense to me at all!

I knew there'd be some karping here about the K-sisters, but K'mon; I know I wasn't the only obsessive stan of "Reading up with the Brontes", waiting breathlessly for each new daguerreotype to drop.



"OH HI!!!!! ... Oh my, you're not who I thought you were."

Wow, awfully tough for a Wednesday.  I liked it.  Standout clue was "good-looking couple?". (Its paired clue was meh though.) And of course the low, low, low point was the chosen second set of sisters.  Just so unnecessary.

Anyhow, fun puzzle.  I wasn't in love with THE Sahara and didn't really know either haka or bel esprit, but the latter two are on me.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

Loved the revealer, and many of the clues throughout, and the fact that "Schumann" is solving to CLARA a lot lately (probably because of the useful letter pattern, but nice anyway). And I was proud that the three top themers were the very first things I filled in, just on the word lengths. But I'll admit that when I got to the bottom of the puzzle, the pairing with that other trio just depressed me. I had to struggle to regain joy in the solve. That's on me (and the times we live in), not the constructor, of course.
So much respect for stacking THE on top of THE and making it work with perfectly respectable fill either side! Cute little detail in a fun puzzle.

After three or four unsuccessful attempts to post a theme-related poem I am quite pleased with -- including one with a fair number of "emus" attached for length --  I cordially invite anyone who's interested (and isn't in a car or on a plane right now) to meander over to the Rex Parker blog and take a peek.
Never thought I'd google whether the Nile or the Rhone has a bigger inflow. Guess I learned something today!

After reading through the comments, I feel safe in saying that BEL ESPRIT was new to everybody who didn't take high school French. "Bon vivant" might raise a few eyebrows at the corner bar, but maybe not at a fancy cocktail party. Would not have made it past my blue pencil.

Which one of the Kardashians was KERRY?

fun puzzle, less the 7 proper nouns in the NW corner. absolutely brutal section that really was just trivia. i appreciate the theme but when your theme is 6 proper nouns... maybe chill out on shoving 15 more into the puzzle? again - this is about solving, not trivia.
Bronte sisters: Litetati.  Kardwhatever sisters: Gutterati.  From A to zzzzzzzzzzzzzzzz.  Otherwise, a good Wed challenge.

Great Wednesday puzzle, and as the youngest of three sisters, the theme was a home run for me. Shout out to the inclusion of the excellent Crying in H Mart, the 2021 memoir by Michelle Zauner. A heartbreaker of a book and a window into the collective trauma of first generation Korean Americans. Zauner is also the founder and lead singer of Japanese Breakfast, an indie pop band formed in 2013. And if you think they are too obscure, they were nominated for two Grammys and were the musical guest on the SNL finale in 2022. See https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/japanese-breakfast-snl-performance-video-1235074090/

Those wonderful Brontes, so sober and serious:
Wrote them all in with a great deal of ease.
Those stupid Kardashians?  Much more mysterious!
Which are the "K" names and which are the "C"s?

SKIT enabled me to change cHLOE to KHLOE.  Is it HACA or HAKA for the dance and is it, therefore, COURTNEY or KOURTNEY.  Such a silly dilemma -- but I'll go and take a peek now.  I didn't know about the corn, beans and squash thing, but this is a cute puzzle with an impressively dense theme.
Sure, it's easy to lament the K sisters. But maybe the best thing they'll ever do is lend their names to a fun Wednesday puzzle. Mission accomplished.
Interesting pairing of theme sisters. Not sure there could be a similar link-up anywhere outside of high-end CW puzzle!

I'm impressed with the stacked THEs! Loved the theme. Got the Brontës right away, but I did try to fit MARYKATE in 45A (hoping for a later ASHLEY and ELIZABETH). 

Not a fan of the Kardashians, but I truly do not understand the ire with their inclusion in a puzzle. Their names, and their (in)famous spellings, are a part of mainstream pop culture knowledge that serves any solver well. Appreciate the juxtaposition from Jill!

Although I don’t rate this puzzle as one of my favorite Wednesday entries, I don’t see why there is any controversy regarding the inclusion of the Kardashian sisters’ names.  I think the juxtaposition of the Brontes from classical literature and the sisters K from pop culture was effective.
French answer for a clue that wasn’t in French feels cheap
Everyone eager to emphasise their superiority by bemoaning Kardashian references, come meet Everyone Else. Aren't you all so special!

My last square was the intersection of 38D and 43A... I had itty as in "itty bitty" and tear as in "on a tear" as a synonym for "scorching hot"/"on fire" (doing extremely well). SEAR makes more sense but I was so sure my mistake was on the non-word BELESPRIT that I got extremely confused. That was about my last choice for where my typo would be, so it turned into a tough Wednesday for me.
What blasphemy, including the Brontë sisters with those other sisters in the same puzzle!

Here's a link to Michelle Zauner's essay in The New Yorker that became the book Crying in H Mart. Hopefully the link will let you read it if you're interested. I think you get a few free articles there each month. https://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/crying-in-h-mart

I rather liked this one... especially having "Over the Rainbow" in my head while I solved it. I used that for a trio of songs I selected for the slideshow at my dear aunt's funeral that I planned back in March so it's bittersweet but more sweet than not. Thought the theme was lovely. I didn't previously know the term THETHREESISTERS but I'm happy to know it now. Sure, the Bronte sibs came to me quickly and the Kardashians did not but once I had a few crosses, I figured it was likely them. I thought it was an interesting juxtaposition of sisters but it didn't sully the puzzle at all for me as it seems for others. After all, sisters gotta be sistering. It's not a trio but here's one of my favorite sister showings. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PG7x8HWbDzU Of course, the follow-up by Bing and Danny is classic! Anyhow, I only knew of KIM off hand so that area was a bit slower but not too bad. BELESPRIT was previously unknown to me but I'm glad to know it now. It's lovely! A few other unknowns, like HMART instead of kMART, but were gettable on the crosses. I feel like it showed up here recently in another puzzle so I didn't fret it much... For some reason, I also appreciated ISEE and ICU connecting not far above EYES and ORBS, which I thought was a fun set. And I liked "A little buggy" for ANT too. Anyhow, I thought it a fun one!

LOL

We're finding all the snoots today!
BEL ESPRIT has been used in English since the 17th century? How many times, including this puzzle.

Random off-topic note: A professional soccer player, Emily Menges, curates a delightful "literary newspaper" that she calls Bel Esprit, possibly inspired by the Hemingway quote found in the masthead. "Either you had Bel Esprit or you did not have it." As an outlet for truly independent art and writing, I find it to be a welcome escape of warmth in a cynical world. https://www.belespritproject.com/
I had a hole in the place where my hope should have been :(

As a hobbyist gardener, a fan of Victorian literature, and as one of four sisters (not to mention a brother), this puzzle hit a feel-good sweetspot for me. Thank you! This made me smile (from ear to ear?)!
Some trivia content is tolerable. But a whole trivia based theme? No thank you! Please don’t do this abomination again.

The K sisters were famously preceded by the Hungarian Gabor sisters, Eva, Zsa Zsa, and Magda, three dazzlingly beautiful, talented women who arrived in the U.S. with their mother, Jolie, at the end of WWII. They were trained singers and dancers, charming, elegant and best of all, truly witty.  Eva Gabor had a role in "Gigi" and Zsa Zsa starred in the John Huston version of "Moulin Rouge." 

Jolie, their mother, had been a prominent jeweler in Hungary. She opened a shop in Palm Springs, where, in 1953, she introduced ornamental metal fingernails studded with rhinestones. (Yes, way back then.) 

From Wikipedia:
In his autobiography, television host Merv Griffin, who was known to spend time with Eva socially, wrote of the Gabor sisters' initial presence in New York and Los Angeles:
    All these years later, it's hard to describe the phenomenon of the three glamorous Gabor girls and their ubiquitous mother. They burst onto the society pages and into the gossip columns so suddenly, and with such force, it was as if they'd been dropped out of the sky.

Unlike the K sisters, the Gabor sisters were the real thing,

One solver's trivia 😢 
is 
another solver's gimme.
                          🚀°
                    °
                        °
                       °
                            °
                          °
                   😄

Couldn’t have been a better time to debut Haka, a few weeks after a Haka spurred thousands to protest in NZ. If you haven’t seen that incredible Haka on the floor of the NZ parliament, it’s very worth a google.
Who else read ‘Eye malady’ as ‘Ay milady’?

I liked this puzzle. No, I’m not a fan of the K sisters, but I guessed both those and the Brontes before anything nearby was filled, even if I needed more crosses to suss out the K names.   
Thanks, Ms. Singer, for a light and breezy Wed!
Lots of fun on a Wednesday. Thanks, Jill Singer and the whole team, including Sam, whose notes are always fun to read.

I am not going to be able to read all the comments, but I just want to thank this community for existing. I did the puzzle this morning, and was very grumpy. I gritted my teeth every time I had to enter a K name. And then I had to go deal with real life and didn't have time to read the comments. 

Now it's evening, and I've had the opportunity to read some of the comments. I want to thank the people who referenced sublime/ridiculous, and those who pointed out that the Ks were on the bottom half. thanks for reversing my grump.
I wonder what the Ks think reading these comments. After all they haven’t personally hurt or harmed anyone here I think.  Not to say they should be idolized from what I know.
Emily Bronte. Kourtney Kardashian.  Together again.
Hardest Wednesday puzzle in a long time! NW had me bad. Too many pop culture references on top of each other
Great puzzle!  I must protest about "showbiz" family.  Dissappointing.  Not entertaining, no talent, reality "stars".  IMNSHO
I’ve done the NYT crossword religiously since 1989. This might be the worst puzzle in 34 years.
Not a fan of the THE stack at 39/42A

I can’t help but think that the Brontë sisters could be at one time considered pop culture and from what I have read, were not necessarily well liked for their progressive views in their day.  Their family had all the makings of what most would consider a scandalous and dysfunctional family today. Makes me wonder who in today’s world will be so revered 125 years from now…what cause or thoughts will be considered so extraordinary generations into the future? 

Also, I don’t think knowing the names or the mere existence of a person or group of people, who may not be in one’s sphere of ongoing interest, is an embarrassment.  The drama in the comments around how NYT Crossword placed/used  “whoever” Kardashian in the puzzle has made me laugh.  Whether they have contributed to the world in a manner that I find important or worthwhile makes no difference in whether it should or shouldn’t be used in a crossword puzzle. 

I have thought about this way too much at this point…I hope everyone has a lovely Thanksgiving. It’s Thanksgiving morning here in Perth and we will be celebrating even though I am the only US citizen in my family here :^)

Hey, a mad woman upstairs? Ghostly hands knocking on windows? Drama on the moors?
Melodrama was all the rage at some points in the nineteenth century, and young women have been seen as frivolous throughout time. And -- reading a novel? Perish the thought! (just kidding!) 
But is melodrama really so removed from our modern version? (Also think of the Victorian socialites of the past -- considered flighty, but then people loved to read about their ballgowns, their summers in Newport, their weddings!)
Personally I loved the mix -- stars of the literary scene, stars of the social scene. I'm an avid reader and also a big pop culture nerd. Unlike, say, Caroline Bingley, I welcome all kinds of entertainment, high and low! 
I can ardently say, the puzzle amused and delighted me!

Hardest one in a while. I've never used the word Gateau, Ersatz, Bel Esprit, nor do I know who Cohen and Doerr are.

I had no problem with the theme. Once I saw Khloe, I knew the others had to be Kim and Kourtney, and then I figured the only other 3 sister group was the Bronte Sisters, and Anne was already on the board.

Desperately ashamed of myself for knowing 45A, 50A, and 61A.  

I've got to make some changes in my life.

@JLin True! O- can give to anyone but can only receive O- (I feel like it would be easy to attribute some sort of moral superiority there if one were into anthropomorphizing blood types...), and O+ can only give to other Rh+ types. (Type AB+ is the universal recipient!)

@Jim 

That reminds me of a joke I think I saw here before.  For anyone who missed it:

A priest, a pastor, and a rabbit walked into a clinic to donate blood. The nurse says to the rabbit: "What's your blood type?"
The rabbit replied with great sadness, "I'm probably a type O".

@JLin - There are dozens of different antigens one can use to type blood and, therefore, dozens of blood groups beyond the Rh factors and the major ABO blood groups. Do you really think the constructors, editors, and 95%+ of the solvers here don't already know that? You see, this is a crossword puzzle, not a treatise on hematology. 

Why limit your gripe to only two of the criteria by which blood can be typed? I think your gripe is incomplete, and wrong, if you don't include the Lutheran and Duffy blood groups. How dare you! ;^)

And there are dozens more you could include, if you want to be as pedantic as you can be about it.

Ahh, Leonard!  He’s that rare bird whose song lyrics work as poetry apart from the music.  His songs tell emotionally charged stories and inspire deep thought and self reflective contemplation.  He stands high in the pantheon of lyricists.  Hallelujah, in its myriad forms is one of the world’s most often covered songs, and he has written so many others just as good.

@Marshall Walthew 

Beautifully said.

I didn't post Hallelujah because it's been so popularized that it's beauty has been diluted, imo.
My favorite cover remains Jeff Buckley's. 

Here's a story you'll appreciate. 
A friend of mine from Austin went to see Buckley play, before he rose to fame (i think it was at La Zona Rosa, a medium-sized club.)
The sound system went kaput midway, but he carried on and sang Hallelujah a capella.
My friend told me that he was so mesmerizing, it was as if everyone had stopped breathing and you could hear a pin drop. 
Charisma, ya know? That's where it's at. 
He definitely left us too soon.

@Andrzej 

I don't think Justin is guessing at the meaning of PILL, just the connection between a medicinal PILL and a human one.

H MART is a gimme for people in some areas of the US; it's an Asian supermarket.  Here in the Northeast, there are quite a few; elsewhere, not that many.  That's why sonnel isn't familiar with the name.

The Flexible Flyer is a gimme to Americans of a certain age.  I'm not so sure that millennials and later would easily recognize it, as kids became less likely to want to play in the snow.

I didn't know the Chinese symbol, either, but with a few crosses, I thought it was inferable.

I didn't know BEL ESPRIT, either, but I got it on crosses, since I recognized the French words emerging.

I know you've made a lot of progress towards knowing this inscrutable American culture, and I'm sure, given a few years, you'll make a lot more!

BTW, I don't know anyone here who changes tires in the winter anymore.  (It was common when I started driving in the 70s.)  Do we have better tires, or better road crews?  Or are we just stupid?

@Andrzej 

My mother would often call me a pill, and she didn't do it endearingly. Did wonders for my self-esteem. Not!

@Steve L 

You Americans have terrible tires. Believe me, I know: I bought an imported car with American tires still on it. They provided almost no grip in winter, and too little of it in the hotter months. That very same car handles like a charm on proper European summer and winter tires, in almost any weather conditions. 

Climate change means many people can get away with all-season tires - I know I did when I had a 4x4 Subaru. But for RWD and FWD cars, proper seasonal tires are a must if you want to stay safe, especially in a country which still experiences most of the features of the four seasons, like Poland.

Thank you all for the comments on PILL 🙂

@Andrzej 

Live carp was also a tradition among Ashkenazi Jews, who purchased the carp to use for making gefilte fish for Passover. The carp were kept in the bathtub. There was even a children's book titled "The Carp in the Bathtub." It was published in 1972, long after the  tradition ended. I remember my grandmother telling me about it.

@Times Rita 

Polish carp were kept in bathtubs, too.

The worst my grandmother could ever say about a person was “he’s such a pill.” It meant an annoying, difficult, contrary person who brought the mood of a room down. Though my mother’s generation and mine wouldn’t have been stumped by the old usage, it was never our word, but belonged to her generation (born 1900-1910). I doubt my nieces and nephews have ever heard it.

@David Connell I'm feeling old now - last night I told my husband he was being a pill (because he was). Maybe it's the patina of old age on that word that makes it feel less argumentative than the more current language that came to mind first.

@Andrzej I'm so surprised no one has mentioned the most modern take on the phrase, from the classic (and mostly terrible, if still charming) Tom Hanks / Meg Ryan romcom You've Got Mail. https://getyarn.io/yarn-clip/62c2913a-225b-4b4b-a4be-d5f391f6e71a ____________________ Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade (emu filler)

@chris Three sisters taste good together, but they are grown together for farming reasons: the corn serves as a growing pole for the climbers, the beans fix nitrogen for the hungry corn, the squash mulches the other plants roots. In places with little water or gardens with less space, corn is often switched out (with annual or perennial sunflowers, for example).

@MOL:
Spellcheck didn't know either Longanberger or Longenberger, and I was bothered to look it up. I believe there were plans to turn the bldg. into a boutique hotel, but I don't know if that ever came to be.

FYI, the sites I visited were: 1) The Newark Earthworks--once a large, 20+ acre complex, the remnants broken up into several sites, one of which sits on a private golf course--you, too, can tee off 2200 y/o archeological monument.
2) Alligator Effigy Mound, located at the end of a residential cul-de-sac outside of Granville, OH--the neighbors walk their dogs on it, so watch you step.
3) Tarleton Cross Mound, in Tarleton, OH--about 1/2 mi. down a path and unmarked, but some new-agers had left coins and a Herkimer diamond on it.
4) Hopewell Culture Natl. Historical Park--several sites, including Mound City group.
5) Adena homestead.

I skipped Great Serpent Mound, as being too far afield; anyway, I had been there a couple times before. And I since have discovered a good site near Xenia, OH. And I know of at least one unmarked site in the Cuyahoga Valley National Park (remember that, kids?).
